habitat: Grows on dung in pastures; widespread in North America.
shortDescription: Dung-loving mushroom with a black spore print, mottled gills, and veil fragments on the cap edge.
benefitsOrToxicity: Probably not toxic, but related species may be mildly hallucinogenic

identification.cap: 1.5-4.0 cm, conic to bell-shaped, smooth, olive-brown to gray-brown with white veil fragments on margin.
identification.gills: Adnate, close, pale grey, becoming blackish and mottled.
identification.stem: 6-12 cm long, slender, hollow, gray-brown. Partial veil remnants on cap margin.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 12-17 x 7-10 µm, elliptical, smooth, with an apical pore

note: Formerly considered a confusing group with P. campanulatus and others, now recognized as one species.
